nodes.text: Teacher test-score value-added (VA) captures teacher quality that causally affects students long-term outcomes in adulthood

Data and research designs: linked administrative school records (grades 3–8, 1989–2009) matched to federal tax records (1996–2011) for ~1.1 million students; two identification strategies used—cross-classroom comparisons conditioning on rich controls and a quasi-experimental teacher-turnover design

Key identification assumptions: (a) selection on observables for cross-class comparisons (unobserved determinants of adult outcomes orthogonal to teacher VA conditional on controls) and (b) high-frequency teacher turnover within school-grade cells is as-good-as-random (quasi-experimental orthogonality)

College attendance: a one standard deviation increase in teacher test-score VA in a single grade raises probability of college attendance at age 20 by about 0.82 percentage points (cross-class) and 0.86 pp (quasi-experiment)

College quality: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA raises the earnings-based index of college quality by about $299 (cross-class) and about $198 (quasi-experiment); also increases probability of attending a high-quality college

Earnings: a one standard deviation improvement in teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by roughly 1.3–1.65 percent (baseline estimate ~1.34 percent ≈ $350), implying a present value lifetime earnings gain of about $7,000 per student (discounted) and ~$39,000 undiscounted
Other adult outcomes: higher teacher VA reduces probability of teenage birth (about −0.61 pp), raises neighborhood socioeconomic status in adulthood and increases 401(k) participation at age 28

Heterogeneity: impacts are slightly larger for females; English teacher VA has larger long-term impacts per unit of test-score gain than math; absolute impacts are larger for higher-income and non-minority students though percent impacts more similar

Test-score fade-out and re-emergence: teachers' impacts on subsequent year test scores fade rapidly and stabilize at ~25% of initial effect after several years, yet long-term impacts on earnings and college outcomes re-emerge in adulthood

Robustness and quasi-experimental evidence: quasi-experimental estimates (teacher turnover) yield estimates similar to cross-class estimates for college outcomes; placebo timing tests, controls for prior scores, and school-year fixed effects support identification

Policy simulation - deselection: replacing a teacher in the bottom 5 percent of the VA distribution with an average teacher would increase present value of students' lifetime income by roughly $250,000 per classroom accounting for drift over a career; using three years of test-score data to deselect yields about $185,000 per classroom

Policy simulation - retention bonuses: paying bonuses to retain high-VA teachers yields small net gains because many high-VA teachers would have remained without bonuses; replacing low-VA teachers is likely more cost-effective in short run though long-run salary increases could attract higher-VA entrants

Estimation practices and procedures: teacher VA estimated leave-year-out, scaled to SD units; regressions use teacher fixed effects to construct outcome residuals, class-level controls, clustering by school-cohort, trimming top 1% VA outliers to avoid likely cheating-induced anomalies

Limitations: insufficient precision for quasi-experimental earnings estimates (smaller sample), measurement error and drift reduce gains from selection on estimated VA, potential behavioral responses (teaching to test or cheating) could erode VA signal when used for high-stakes evaluation

Conclusion: test-score-based teacher VA measures are informative proxies for teachers' long-term impacts and could be a useful tool for evaluation and policy if implemented cautiously and complemented by safeguards against manipulation and measures addressing limitations
